articles.headline: New Agency Plans to Make Over Mortgage Market
articles.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, seeking to improve fairness and clarity for borrowers, is moving to establish its legitimacy and quiet its critics.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, seeking to improve fairness and clarity for borrowers, is moving to establish its legitimacy and quiet its critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the next six months, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a newly formed regulator vilified by the right, intends to overhaul the home mortgage market as a first step toward improving its fairness and clarity.

articles.headline: Trade Group for Bankers Regulates a Key Rate
articles.snippet: Following news over Barclays’ role in the Libor rate-fixing scandal, more attention is being paid to the British Bankers’ Association, the powerful trade group that oversees Libor.
articles.abstract: Following news over Barclays’ role in the Libor rate-fixing scandal, more attention is being paid to the British Bankers’ Association, the powerful trade group that oversees Libor.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was big news when the Barclays chairman, Marcus Agius, resigned Monday over his bank’s role in the Libor rate-fixing scandal. Less noticed was his other resignation that same day.

articles.headline: Shots by Murdoch at Romney Play Out to Conservative Core
articles.snippet: A stern Wall Street Journal editorial was a reminder of Mitt Romney’s failure to win the trust of a group that pays close attention to Rupert Murdoch’s cable channels and newspapers.
articles.abstract: A stern Wall Street Journal editorial was a reminder of Mitt Romney’s failure to win the trust of a group that pays close attention to Rupert Murdoch’s cable channels and newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear Rupert Murdoch tell it lately, Mitt Romney lacks stomach and heart. He “seems to play everything safe.” And he is not nearly as tough as he needs to be on President Obama.

articles.headline: Commercial Mortgages Show How Bad It Got
articles.snippet: As commercial mortgage loans issued during the boom years come due, the insanity of that market may be exemplified by what happened at the Pinnacle Group.
articles.abstract: As commercial mortgage loans issued during the boom years come due, the insanity of that market may be exemplified by what happened at the Pinnacle Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just five years ago, the commercial real estate market was thriving. The delinquency rate on mortgage loans was at a record low, and the volume of new mortgages being sold to investors was at a record high.

articles.headline: Chinese Cars Make Valuable Gains in Emerging Markets
articles.snippet: Chinese cars are growing in popularity in countries like Brazil, Russia and Saudi Arabia, where buyers are more interested in low cost than in Western brands.
articles.abstract: Chinese cars are growing in popularity in countries like Brazil, Russia and Saudi Arabia, where buyers are more interested in low cost than in Western brands.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For more than a decade, automakers around the world have been nervously awaiting the day when China would start exporting sizable numbers of cars to the West.

articles.headline: India Weighs Providing Free Drugs at State-Run Hospitals
articles.snippet: A proposal to provide essential drugs free to hospital patients would fill a gap in health care at India’s state-owned hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.
articles.abstract: A proposal to provide essential drugs free to hospital patients would fill a gap in health care at India’s state-owned hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In what would be a landmark increase in the Indian government’s spending on public health, New Delhi is completing a proposal to provide hundreds of essential drugs free to patients in government-run hospitals and clinics at a cost of nearly $5 billion over five years, officials said Thursday.

articles.headline: Earthquake Relief Where Haiti Wasn’t Broken
articles.snippet: As rebuilding lags, the showcase project of reconstruction is an industrial park in an undamaged area, a venture that risks benefiting foreign companies more than Haiti itself.
articles.abstract: As rebuilding lags, the showcase project of reconstruction is an industrial park in an undamaged area, a venture that risks benefiting foreign companies more than Haiti itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACOL, Haiti — On the first anniversary of the Jan. 12, 2010, earthquake, in a sleepy corner of northeast Haiti far from the disaster zone, the Haitian government began the process of evicting 366 farmers from a large, fertile tract of land to clear the way for a new industrial park.

articles.headline: Crammed Into Cheap Bunks, Dreaming of Future Digital Glory
articles.snippet: Sleep next to heaps of laundry; eat ham out of the package; work till 3 in the morning. Such is life at “hacker hostels,” where young digerati network and keep their expenses down.
articles.abstract: Sleep next to heaps of laundry; eat ham out of the package; work till 3 in the morning. Such is life at “hacker hostels,” where young digerati network and keep their expenses down.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — From the outside it’s just a beige three-story building in a quiet residential neighborhood. But inside, in a third-floor apartment, there are enough Ikea bunk beds to sleep 10 people, crammed into two bedrooms. The living room is bare except for a futon, a tiny desk and laptop power cables strewed across the hardwood floor like a nest of snakes.

articles.headline: Syrian’s Defection Signals Eroding Support for Assad
articles.snippet: While Brig. Gen. Manaf Tlass drew world attention when he fled on Thursday, President Bashar al-Assad’s bigger military challenge is the swelling number of silent objectors in Syria.
articles.abstract: While Brig. Gen. Manaf Tlass drew world attention when he fled on Thursday, President Bashar al-Assad’s bigger military challenge is the swelling number of silent objectors in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The defection of a young general close to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has provided the most telling sign yet of eroding support for his government among even the most elite and trusted Sunni Muslims, who serve as a critical pillar of the security forces and civilian administration.

articles.headline: Job Weakness Starts to Shape Election Tone
articles.snippet: With Friday’s report showing the unemployment rate stuck at 8.2 percent, what looked like a blip has become a streak, and the economy is unlikely to pick up much before November.
articles.abstract: With Friday’s report showing the unemployment rate stuck at 8.2 percent, what looked like a blip has become a streak, and the economy is unlikely to pick up much before November.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is increasingly apparent what the economy will look like when President Obama faces voters in November: pretty much what it looks like today.

articles.headline: Afghan Conflict Losing Air Power as U.S. Pulls Out
articles.snippet: The crucial role played by American warplanes in Afghanistan raises questions about the prospects for the fight against the Taliban in the future.
articles.abstract: The crucial role played by American warplanes in Afghanistan raises questions about the prospects for the fight against the Taliban in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Death stopped Abdul Qayum, a Taliban commander in Afghanistan’s Zabul Province, in a fiery flash and roar.
